answer_html: The converse is:If I buy a new car, then I will win the lottery.
answer_latex: The converse is:If I buy a new car, then I will win the lottery.
hints_html:
Let \(L\) be the statement “win the lottery” and let \(B\) be the statement buy a new car. Then the above can be rewritten as

\(L \Rightarrow B\)

What is the converse of this statement?

The converse of \(A \Rightarrow B\) is \(B \Rightarrow A\)
hints_latex:
Let $L$ be the statement ``win the lottery'' and let $B$ be the
statement buy a new car. Then the above can be rewritten as

$L \Rightarrow B$

What is the converse of this statement?
The converse of $A \Rightarrow B$ is $B \Rightarrow A$
hints_raw:
Let <math> L </math> be the statement "win the lottery" and let <math> B </math> be the statement buy a new car. Then the above can be rewritten as

<math> L \Rightarrow B </math>

What is the converse of this statement?
The converse of <math> A \Rightarrow B </math> is <math> B \Rightarrow A </math>
question: 1 (c)
sols_html:
The converse is:

If I buy a new car, then I will win the lottery.

The converse is:

If I buy a new car, then I will win the lottery.
sols_raw:
The converse is: 

If I buy a new car, then I will win the lottery.
statement_html:
State the converse of this statement:

“If I will win the lottery, then I will buy a new car.”
statement_latex:
State the converse of this statement:

``If I will win the lottery, then I will buy a new car.''
statement_raw:
State the converse of this statement:

"If I will win the lottery, then I will buy a new car."
